thread.title: Metro cash, Article 50 and a memorable election: The key moments in British politics in 2017

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Metro cash, Article 50 and a memorable election: The key moments in British politics in 2017
text:

We’re coming to the end of an historic year in British politics . 
Some of the events of the past 12 months will have a long-lasting impact on the United Kingdom, on the political parties at Westminster and on the North East . 
Highlights include funding for new Metro trains and a North of the Tyne devolution deal. 
On the other hand there were stark warnings about Brexit as Article 50 was triggered by MPs. 
Here, political editor Jonathan Walker takes a look back at the key moments of 2017. Theresa May says “nothing has changed” An eventful speech by Theresa May to conference (Image: Daily Mirror) 
The big political event of 2017 was the General Election on June 8. 
Theresa May didn’t need to call an election. But she thought it would be a chance to win a landslide majority. 
Conservatives thought they could make a major breakthrough in the North East, thanks to Theresa May’s personal popularity and because she was seen as the champion of Brexit, which the region overwhelmingly backed in the referendum. 
There was talk of seats such as Tynemouth, Bishop Auckland, Sedgefield and Darlington turning blue. 
It didn’t happen. The election proved to be a massive misjudgment on the part of Mrs May. 
She lost her majority in the House of Commons and the person who benefitted was Jeremy Corbyn . 
Many Labour MPs expected the party to lose seats and Mr Corbyn to stand down as party leader. But when Labour gained 30 seats, it meant Mr Corbyn’s position was safe. 
Of course, we still have a Conservative Government. It’s easy to forget that Labour lost. 
The election result means Mrs May is almost certain to stand down as Conservative leader some time before the next election. 
And the most memorable moment of the campaign came on May 22, when she announced a partial u-turn over reforms to social care funding popularly known as the “dementia tax”. 
Mrs May insisted: “Nothing has changed”. We all knew that it had. 
It was the moment when her claim to provide “strong and stable” leadership no longer appeared credible. The media described her as “weaky and wobbly” instead. A new North of Tyne mayor Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council, Norma Redfearn, directly-elected Mayor of North Tyneside and Councillor Peter Alan Jackson, leader of Northumberland Council (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
There was a huge development in the long-running saga of North East devolution in November, when Chancellor Philip Hammond announced he was backing plans for a new ‘North of Tyne’ combined authority and mayor. 
Elections for the mayor will take place in 2019, with an interim mayor - probably a council leader - appointed in the meantime. 
Newcastle City Council, North Tyneside Council and Northumberland County Council will all be included in the new authority. 
It will get funding of £600m over 30 years but the final sum could be a lot more, according to the Treasury. It says the deal will boost the local economy by £1.1bn and attract £2.1bn in private investment. 
So is the debate about devolution over? 
Not really, because it raises questions about South Tyneside, Sunderland, Gateshead and Durham, the councils that are not involved. 
They will have a combined authority and mayor to the north as well as the Tees Valley authority and mayor to the south. 
The North of Tyne councils have decided to go off and do their own thing - but they don’t deny that they’d be delighted if other North East councils chose to join them eventually. 
Whether that will ever happen remains to be seen. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now New trains for the Tyne and Wear Metro ... at last 
The Government was keen to sow how much it is investing in the North East, as part of a concerted effort to show it was committed to the Northern Powerhouse - and that this “Powerhouse” included more than Manchester and the North West. 
Announcements included £42m for the International Advanced Manufacturing Park, close to the A19 and north of Nissan’s carmaking plant, designed to create more than 5,000 jobs. 
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling also pledged that the A1 will be dualled from Northumberland to Scotland. Read More MP fighting South Tyneside hospital cuts says she won't be bullied into silence 
But the biggest single announcement came in November’s Budget - when Chancellor Philip Hammond said £337m would be made available to replace ageing trains on the Tyne and Wear Metro. 
The carriages have bene in use since the 1980s and well past their sell by date. Transport authority Nexus, councils and MPs had been lobbying the Government for cash to replace the unreliable stock. 
New trains could now be in use by 2021. 
The Treasury had been in talks with Nexus about whether to provide the money directly or to impose a complex private finance initiative deal. But in a major win for the region, the Chancellor announced the funding would take the form of a direct grant. Triggering Article 50 to take us out of the European Union (Image: AP) 
Only one MP voted against - Newcastle North Labour MP Catherine McKinnell . 
It meant that Prime Minister Theresa May had the authority to tell the EU officially that we planned to leave. 
And she did just that, in March. 
As a result, the UK will officially leave the EU on March 29 2019. 
But it didn’t end the debate about Brexit and there have been a series of House of Commons votes since then. 
MPs who refused to go along with the Government’s line have been called “traitors” and “mutineers” by some newspapers. 
They’re not. Their job is to use their judgment in the House of Commons and do what they believe is in the best interests of their constituents, not to blindly do what the Government wants. 
Mrs May suffered her first Commons defeat over Brexit in December. But that won’t stop it happening. 
The Labour leadership, and most Labour MPs, have supported Brexit. In some cases, they might have done it reluctantly, saying they feel obliged to respect the result of the 2016 referendum. 
As long as this continues, Brexit is certain to happen. Nissan warns the wrong type of Brexit will be a disaster Staff working at Nissan's car plant in Sunderland. About 80% of the cars produced at Sunderland are exported, primarily to Europe, which has created thousands of jobs. (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
What’s not clear is what sort of Brexit we’re going to get. 
The Government seems to be divided about how close it thinks the UK should remain to the EU after Brexit. 
Labour is even more unclear, with members of the Shadow Cabinet contradicting each other over whether there should be a second referendum. Labour says it wants a “jobs first” Brexit, but also insists on ending freedom of movement which will threaten jobs by making it harder for the UK to retain single market access. 
The potential dangers of getting it wrong were highlighted in February when carmaker Nissan said leaving the European Union without a trade deal could cost its Sunderland operation half a billion pounds every year - and put its future in doubt.
